How can I get the 14 books that were removed from the Bible? I think you are talking about the deuterocanonical texts that you’ll find in Catholic and Orthodox translations. That’s easy; pick up a Catholic translation. The NAB is probably the most commonly-available here in the US. My favorite Catholic translation is the New Jerusalem Bible, but you might have to order it online unless you’re near a university, Catholic bookstore, or large public library. If you’re a KJV person, the 1611 version did contain the Apocrypha, and this looks like a place to find it: Read the King James Version w/ Apocrypha Free Online Just as a note, those texts are also deuterocanonical in the Hebrew Bible. That is, they’re part of the Jewish tradition, but don’t hold the weight of authority found in the Torah.

You can read any book or periodical you want. The question is, is it expedient to do so. The 39 books of the old testament (or Tanakh to a Jew) and 27 books of the New Testament were accepted by all. There are some books called Apocrypha that are accepted by some. There is the Pseudepigrapha which are writings rejected by all. If you read any/all of them, anything outside of the 66 books are not to be taken over the 66 books for doctrine. Some may disagree with me because their church may base many of their doctrines from writings outside the 66 books of Holy writ. The expediency relates to your intent. Only God knows your heart and purposes. You are accountable to God, not men. Jesus said: Luk 21:33 KJV Heaven and earth shall pass away: but my words shall not pass away. and Rev 22:18-20 KJV 18 For I testify unto every man that heareth the words of the prophecy of this book, If any man shall add unto these things, God shall add unto him the plagues that are written in this book: 19 And if any man shall take away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God shall take away his part out of the book of life, and out of the holy city, and from the things which are written in this book. 20 He which testifieth these things saith, Surely I come quickly. Amen. Even so, come, Lord Jesus. Hope that helps. All Scriptures are from the King James version of the Bible.

Get a copy of the Orthodox Study Bible. It is the original Septuagint translation from Aramaic to Greek, finished in about 200 BC for the Jews in the Diaspora. It is the Bible that Jesus and the Disciples quote from, and it contains all of the books the Protestants removed during the Reformation. It is the version used by the Eastern Orthodox Church. Most Protestant Bibles are based on the Masoretic text, which was done by a group of Jewish scholars between 700 and 1000 AD. There is a Septuagint on line, But I prefer the translation of the Orthodox Study Bible, and the notes are very extensive. It is available in both hard and electronic formats. They were not lost, they were not disappeared, they were simply not used. They were considered heretical because they did not agree in doctrine but now by scholars they are important enough to show how the current understandings of Jesus and Judaism have grown to be understood.

I’m assuming since you say “removed” you mean the books that were originally in the KJV which would be the same as the ones in the Catholic bible which hasn’t changed. The list of books in the Orthodox bible is slightly different than the Catholic. You can still find bibles that contain the apocrypha, even some of the modern protestant translations, but you will probably have better luck shopping around online than actually finding one in a bookstore. The other option is to buy a book that contains just the apocrypha. These books really aren’t that hard to find.

If you are really interested in understanding what the full meaning of the Bible contains, by all means start with the Apocrypha, but don't stop there. Jesus promises to send teachers to explain everything to us (John 14:17 15:26 16:13). How else can His promise to keep the Word Alive be fulfilled with regular updates to account for changes in language? Study also the works of the spirit of truth, both in ancient and modern times. I suggest starting with the most recent of these visits.
